evidence_items.text: A tug driving instructor (tug instructor) and trainee tug driver (trainee driver) were seated beside each other in the tug. The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so. The headset operator continued walking on the right side of the tug, abeam its cabin. The wingman was on the left just ahead of the tug.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.
The tug instructor pulled the aircraft forward off the fence then stopped the tug.

roots_spec.exclusion_clause: Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root
Not explained by any other root

node.statement: Communication/coordination breakdown among crew was evident and documented during the early phase of the historical timeline for Boeing 737-8AS 9H-QAA on 12-25.

assumptions: The incident of the aircraft moving beyond the TRP might imply coordination issues but is not definitive proof of communication breakdown
defeaters: Explicit evidence of documented communication breakdown among crew during early phase
Clear statements or reports indicating coordination failure

quotes.exact_quote: The flight crew were in communication with the headset operator via the aircraft’s interphone.
The trainee driver decided to stop the pushback and asked the tug instructor to take over.

After swapping seats the instructor recommenced the pushback, correcting the aircraft back onto the taxiway centreline. He continued to reassure and advise the trainee while performing the pushback, looking at her while doing so.

The aircraft’s nosewheel reached the ‘Tug release point’ (TRP) ground markings. However, it continued moving beyond the TRP with its engine at idle and hit the blast barrier at the end of the cul-de-sac.

outcome.reasoning_summary: The evidence shows communication between flight crew and headset operator and interaction between tug instructor and trainee, but no explicit documentation of communication or coordination breakdown among crew during the early phase; the incident of the aircraft moving beyond the TRP suggests possible coordination issues but is not directly attributed to communication failure (H1-H4).
outcome.uncertainty_source: absence of direct statements or documentation of communication breakdown; ambiguity in interpreting the incident as caused by communication failure

defeaters: Evidence of mechanical or control system malfunction during the event
Reports or data indicating failure in aircraft control systems
outcome.reasoning_summary: No evidence indicates any mechanical or control failure; all evidence describes human actions and aircraft movement without mention of mechanical issues (H1-H5).
